Layman Lectures
Begin At McCoy
All About Science
A course of 11 scientific lectures for laymen opened last
Tuesday night at McCoy College
with a talk by Dr. S. Fred Singer, associate professor of physics
at the University of Maryland.
Dr. Singer's topic is "Physical
Problems of Earth Satellites and
Space Vehicles."
In giving details of the series,
McCoy College announced that,
the discussions are "intended
for the layman who is interested
in obtaining a better understanding of developments in various
important fields of scientific inquiry."
The first part of each class
period will be devoted to an informal presentation by experts
nationally known in the different fields represented. After each
talk there will be an opportunity
for questions from the class.

Security, Peace,
Stability—Goals
Says Dr. Long
"The purpose of politics . . .
is to get elected," stated Dr.
Clarence D. Long, speaking to a
young Democratic gathering on
Wednesday evening, October 8,
at the Headquarters of the
Young Democratic Clubs of
Maryland.
Dr. Long listed the following
as the six Democratic goals of
politics. (1) "The provision for
some kind of security." (2) "The
provision of opportunity .. . social and economic." He said that
this goal can be provided by a
decent educational system and
that "most social advancement
comes from economic advancement."
(3) "Stability." (4) "Equal
protection of our laws . . regardless of distinguishing characteristics." (5) "A strong national defense." (6) "Peace."
He expressed his confidence that
these goals will be fulfilled, if
we only have enough time.
Dr. Long gave several reasons
why he is out supporting his
former opponents (Tawes,
D'Alesandro, et. al.). "I did not
run as an independent; I ran as
an independent Democrat."
He said that if he had been
elected, he would have expected
their support. "I believe in the
Democratic party. . . . By and
large in the long run I believe it
is the best party for America."
"Almost never do you .. . talk
about issues at a political gathering," said Dr. Long, citing
things concerning politics which
dismayed him.
"Most people who ate in politics are in it for what they can
get out of it. .. . The number of
people who are in politics for
idealitsic purposes seems to be
quite small. . . . The average
person takes very little interest
in politics," continued Dr. Long.
On education, Dr. Long said,
"Education ... is awfully disillusioning. .. . An educated person is one who can become disillusioned without becoming bitter. . . . There is nothing worse
than an educated dumbell."

Don't tell me: I know how busy you've been! I know all the
things you've had to do in the opening days of the school year—
registering, paying fees, finding lodgings, entering a drag race,
getting married, building a cage for your raccoon. But now,

hands and take, for the first time, a long, leisurely look at our
Campus.
Ready? Let's go!
We begin our tour over here on this lovely stretch of greensward called The Mall. The Mall, as we all know, was named in
honor of our distinguished alumnus Fred Mall, inventor of the
Opposing thumb. Before Mr. Mall's invention, the thumb could
not be pressed or clicked against the other fingers. As a result,
millions of castanet makers were out of work. Today however,
thanks to Mr. Mall, one out of every three Americans is gainfully employed making castanets. (The other two make croquet
wickets.) Mr. Mall is now 106 years old and living in seclusion
on a sea cliff in Wellington, Kansas, but the old gentleman is
far from idle. He still works twelve hours a day in his laboratory, and in the last year has invented the tuna, the cuticle,
and lint.
